abstract.p: Diane R Richards letter holds David Thomson, in article on Orson Wells and William Randolph Hearst, has fallen into trap of confusing Welles's finished work Citizen Kane with materials used in making of film (S)

block.p: The question in the headline of David Thomson's article is irrelevant [''Was It Citizen Hearst or Citizen Welles?'']. So astute a critic as Mr. Thomson has fallen into the trap of confusing Welles's finished work ''Citizen Kane'' with the materials used in the making of it.

The question in the headline of David Thomson's article is irrelevant [''Was It Citizen Hearst or Citizen Welles?'']. So astute a critic as Mr. Thomson has fallen into the trap of confusing Welles's finished work ''Citizen Kane'' with the materials used in the making of it.

The moviemaker, like any artist, is free to manipulate his or her materials for the purpose of achieving a unified effect (the completed film). Hearst was a giant of the newspaper world, with the immense power to inffluence public opinion. Welles had tasted the power of radio to confuse and terrify in his program ''The War of the Worlds.'' But the analogy between the two stops there.

Welles and his screenwwriter in ''Kane,'' Herman Mankiewicz, crafted a character from boyhood to old age: the heart-breaking cycle of trauma, elation, megalomania, failure and despair. This portrait is neither Hearst nor Welles. The protagonist is separated in youth from his needy, misguided parents and set on a lavish but fatal course. Suffering is at the center of ''Citizen Kane,'' not the stature of William Randolph Hearst nor the ambition of Orson Welles.
